The assertion was introduced at #874

do we know why producer gets disconnected? because this assertion was added on bug-fix if there is a message-drop at broker then producer should not disconnect and ignore the message drop. So, if producer is disconnecting due to the same reason then it could be the issue. if the reason is something else then we can merge this fix.

run integration tests

what happens if pulsar-cluster or topics don't have schema registry available/enable? in that case, will there be a way to submit function without using schema registry? I mean schema-registry can't be mandatory for submitting function because schema-registry is optional feature for pulsar topic as well. so, this is a backward compatible change.? and existing functionality will still work.. right?
@jerrypeng I have sent out #2398 for review. I think this one can be closed in favor of using #2398

The concept of serde still exists. Thus users will still be able to submit functions with serde attached to topics. Internally however we map everything into schema, but the results are going to be transparent.

@rdhabalia Existing functions will still work without change. You can still provide a SerDe class or a custom schema (which is essentially a serde, since it lacks broker support to be stored on server side). 

With Serde or custom schema, the schema registry is completely bypassed.

Jia, I have done that in #2410
a dup
Is any idea to implement this feature?  I'm interest to join the discussion of design and contribute for this feature.

>  was the proxy auth action ever added?
No, and we don't need to

> @jai1 <https://github.com/jai1> @merlimat <https://github.com/merlimat> is
authRole correct here? Surely if we are coming from the proxy and
originalPrincipal is set, we should be checking if the original principle
which can access the resource?

The code looks convoluted but I think it's correct so basically if,  '
originalPrincipal  != null' then check if both proxy role (authRole) and
client role (original Principal) can lookup on the topic. So on line 251
(first call to canLookupAsync) we check whether the proxy (authRole) has
permission to lookup then on line 261 (call to lookupTopicAsync) we check
if client role (original Principal)  has permission to lookup.

Basic reasoning for this was that we don't want the proxy to have access to
all Pulsar namespaces - we want to have a configuration where proxy X can
only access namespace Y.

wrote:

This phenomenon seems to happen when the consumer is receiving a lot of messages. For example, it is prone to happen when the consumer connects to a topic with a large number of messages in the backlog.
